moves.1. Nf3: Greetings! This is my first annotated game, simply because my adversary had a high rating, so beating him became my record. Actually, as I noticed, he's not a genuine 1700 rating range type of player, because he got it by winning over others players having the 1200-1600 rating range. Anyway...He started the development with the king side knight.
moves.1... Nf6: When we started the game, I was at the end of the "learn how to open" phase. Back then, I responded with the same king side knight. I no longer do that... :)
moves.2. b3: Yada, yada, yada, the typical opening, continued by Bb2, Nc3 and a short castle.
moves.3. Bb2 Bg7 4. c4 O-O: His majesty goes to a safe place.
moves.5. g3: Okay, so he intends to dominate both long diagonals...
moves.5... Nc6: Back in the days I used to go Nc6 before c5. Nowadays I do it the other way around.
moves.6. Bg2 d6: I open up my white bishop.
moves.7. d3: A strange move...or maybe I'm just not illuminated enough. :)
moves.8. Nbd2: Okay, now I get it...he's coming for my king.
moves.8... Ne7: So, in response, I attack it as well...:))
moves.9. e4: Nice move, it passed my attention, I'm pretty much blocked there with the traveling knight...I can't and won't go back to c6...I would look like a fool...
moves.10. O-O: Finally, he puts his suveranity into safety.
moves.10... a5: Attacking...the wrong side, but still attacking...
moves.11... Nc6: Eventually, I get where I want with both the c pawn and the queen side knight.
moves.12. a3: Okay, so now he controls the entire 4th rank...so what? :)
moves.12... Qb6: Placing your queen on the enemy king's diagonal, especially in a "waiting, to errupt" type of attack, is always good.
moves.13. Rb1: He thought I wanted to achieve something on that file.
moves.13... Be6: I'm just developing my pieces...that's all.
moves.14. Re1: He's preparing for war with the heavy pieces.
moves.15. Nf1: The only possible square for his queen side knight.
moves.15... Rfe8: Face to face, cowboy! Heads up!
moves.18... Bxd5 19. cxd5: The exchange takes place, we both have doubled peasants.
moves.19... Qa7: I open up some space for the b pawn.
moves.20... Nh5: Hoping to get that g3 pawn...not the best of moves by the way.
moves.21. Qf3: It's not gonna' happen', not today...
moves.22. g4: WTF?!? I didn't see this coming.
moves.22... c4: Realising that moving the knight back to f6 will make only worse, because of g5 or e5, I give him something to think about on the other side.
moves.23. bxc4: He calls my bluff, instead of taking my knight.
moves.23... bxc4 24. dxc4: Not the best move, I'd say, when his king is on my queen's diagonal.
moves.26. gxh5: It's too late, mate, especially when my black bishop is in the nearby of a possibly promoting pawn.
moves.27. Red1 Qd4: With a single move, defending two pieces...God, I love and hate queens...:))
moves.28. hxg6: Trying to fork my king and rook.
moves.29. Qe2: The only sane solution to the situation.
moves.29... Bxa3: Only because it evened out the material standings.
moves.30. Rxb8 Rxb8 31. Rxd2: Okay. In this move there's the key to the game. I was kind of afraid that he will take it with the queen, which would have been the good move. Now I can check his majesty.
moves.31... Rb1+: He can defend with three pieces or run.
moves.33. Kg3 Bb4: Not achieving any progress in checkmating him, I start an attack with a good positioned bishop.
moves.34. Rc2: Didn't understand why did he chosed that specific square...
moves.35. Qf2: Nice, opened up the e3 square for another check.
moves.35... Re3+ 36. Kg4 Qd1+: And so on...I was hoping he would put some pieces between, but he preferred running.
moves.37. Kg5 Qh5+: My king at f7 would have been nice...
moves.38. Kf6 Bc3+: I'm sorry mate, but I want to checkmate you.
moves.39. Rxc3: Didn't think he'll sacrifice it, but he had an ingenious plan all along, as you'll see...
moves.39... Rxc3: The fool me exploits the situation, without anticipating his next move.
moves.40. Qb2: Bang!!! WTF?!? Imminent checmate against my king or losing the rook? I didn't see this coming...
moves.40... Qh4+: I was lucky, I managed to think a way out of the situation.
moves.41. Ke6 Rxc4: For material advantage, clearing the c file and perhaps because of promotion danger.
moves.42. Qb8+ Kg7: The only possible square to run to.
moves.44. f5: The second big wrong move from my opponent, not seeing that if we both accept the exchanges, the e file will free up.
moves.44... gxf5 45. exf5: From this move on, I'm going after his queen.
moves.46... Qe5+: Only square to go is f7.
moves.47. Kf7 Qg7+: He resignes, because of my skewer upon the king against his queen.
